intro: Geissaspis emarginata, commonly known as the margined geissowood, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its small, fragrant flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant has lance-shaped leaves with a distinctive white margin, giving it its common name. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and is of particular interest to botanists and conservationists.
